moves.1. e4: e4 open to me is the strongest move from any opponent.  d4 runs a close second choice to e4 open.  I am Black and my usual is the Caro Kann against e4....
moves.1... c6: ...and so it is my most comfortable defense against the strongest White Open: e4.
moves.2. d4: A strong and expected response to the seemingly diminutive first move of Caro Kann Defense.
moves.2... d5: The usual thing to do here in Caro Kann...
moves.3. Nc3: A usual thing for White to do....
moves.3... dxe4: a usual thing for me to do...
moves.4. Nxe4: the usual expected response to my usual.  Now comes the Caro Kann Defense to attack the knight:
moves.4... Bf5: A usual Caro Kann maneuver--but keep in mind Caro has more options in most times to usual moves by White to deal with the diminutive Caro Kann c6 defense to e4.....
moves.5. Ng3: My bishop is out and he needs to avoid capture.  I have to place him in a safe yet ready place for use.
moves.5... Bg6: Best place and the usual for Caro Kann.
moves.6. Nf3: This is an expected move for White to make.  In fact White has been doing the standard moves since e4 open on my favorite: The Caro Kann.
moves.6... e6: I inch forward with another seemingly diminutive move....
moves.7. Be2: Usually I would have expected White to apply pressure King Side by going after my Q Bishop.  Not the case here. However, on the surface, this seems to be a safe move for White allowing 0-0 in the next move.  This is where White, who should be on the Offensive, becomes Defensive.  White should either attack and go out in a blaze of glory or resign or play a long game against a slow Black Defense like the Ruy Lopez.  Or Giuoco Piano. Or French Defense.  I am set in my ways.  The Caro Kann can suddenly turn the tables with attack at any time.
moves.7... Bd6: Castling for White in a protective ensconced corner of the board is now under contemplation....
moves.9. Be3: A build up around the White King while developing.
moves.9... Ngf6: The other Knight coming into sequence and position with the other Knight coming across more laterally than vertically--in Caro Kann the Knights are used beyond the usual defenses.  They act in sequence like two rooks mated.
moves.10. c4: White is pushing Infantry at the expense of the range of his Bishops....
moves.10... h6: Since White is locking himself down into defense my only choice is to continue an attack.  It continues with another diminutive move common in the Caro Kann.
moves.11. Qd2: I don't think this is the best position for White's Queen but as long as White's own lockdown is in effect why not apply more pressure to the g3 Knight?
moves.12. Rac1: With this move there is a collection of locked down pieces all together that should be scattered instead of in one place for a grenade....
moves.13. Ne5: I haven't taken the time to castle but another opportunity to make the most of my grenade into the pack of pieces seems irresistible.
moves.14. Nxd7: It is really too late at this point for White to offend.
moves.14... Nxf1:
He can have my Queen in the rear zone and I can have his with the grenade depending on his choice here. 
White with e4 Open (strongest White Open) is defeated with the Caro Kann Defense.  White resigns.
